title: My Personal Website
text:
Biography
I grew up in Metro Detroit. I went to Lehigh University for my undergraduate degree where I received a B.A. in International Relations & Economics. I also received a minor in Sustainable Development and a certificate in Global Citizenship. I received an M.S. in Applied Demography from the University of Texas at San Antonio, where I am still a doctoral student.
My research is concerned with women, childbearing people, and children. I study how contextual factors (i.e. climate/ conflict patterns or community gender norms) influence infant/child/ maternal health, fertility decision-making, and gender equity. My doctoral dissertation is on fertility autonomy in Uganda.
Outside of work you can find me running, reading, making ceramics, gardening, or doing a paint by numbers. You can also find me making latte art, as I also work as a part-time barista at a local coffee shop.
I live in Austin, Texas with my partner and our dog.

title: My Personal Website
text:
Other Work
At ISRDI, I contributed to the Spatial Analysis and Health Research Hub. See some highlights below.

From MODIS to VIIRS: The Latest Source for NDVI Data- Finn Roberts & Rebecca Luttinen
Anticipating the Future: Important terminology- Molly Brown & Rebecca Luttinen
Estimating the now and predicting the future: Fertility rate estimation and population projection – Rebecca Luttinen & Elizabeth Heger Boyle
Measuring Dietary Diversity using DHS data – Devon Kristiansen & Rebecca Luttinen
Harnessing CHC-CMIP6 Climate Scenario Data to Explore the Future– Rebecca Luttinen & Jessie Pinchoff
Using Historical and Projected Climate Data to Forecast Child Malnutrition – Rebecca Luttinen & Jessie Pinchoff
